title: Rethinking thinking - Trevor Maber

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the model that describes how our experiences are processed in our subconscious brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ladder of Emotions

options.label: B
options.text: The Ladder of Inference

options.label: C
options.text: The Ladder of Assumptions

options.label: D
options.text: The Ladder of Conclusions

multiple-choice.question: According to the Ladder of Inference model, what happens on the second rung?

options.label: A
options.text: We assign meaning to the information we have filtered through

options.label: B
options.text: We filter in specific information and details from our experience

options.label: C
options.text: We develop assumptions based on the meaning we created

options.label: D
options.text: We take action based on our adjusted beliefs

multiple-choice.question: On which rung of the Ladder of Inference do we develop conclusions based on our assumptions?

options.label: A
options.text: Third rung

options.label: B
options.text: Fourth rung

options.label: C
options.text: Fifth rung

options.label: D
options.text: Sixth rung

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of being able to "short-circuit" our own Ladder of Inference?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more reactive to our experiences

options.label: B
options.text: We become less aware of our assumptions

options.label: C
options.text: We are able to make more informed conclusions and take better actions

options.label: D
options.text: We become more emotional in our responses

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the benefit of being mindful of our own Ladder of Inference?

options.label: A
options.text: We can better understand others' perspectives

options.label: B
options.text: We can become more defensive in our interactions

options.label: C
options.text: We can make more assumptions about others

options.label: D
options.text: We can help others to see their own Ladder of Inference

options.label: B
options.text: The point where both vendors are a quarter mile from the middle of the beach

options.label: C
options.text: The point where one vendor is at the center of the beach and the other is at one end

options.label: D

title: The power of a great introduction - Carolyn Mohr

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended approach to writing a literary analysis introduction?

options.label: A
options.text: Write the introduction first to set the tone for the rest of the essay.

options.label: B
options.text: Write the introduction last, after drafting and revising the analysis.

options.label: C
options.text: Write the introduction and thesis statement simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: Write the introduction after researching the historical context of the topic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of asking questions when analyzing a literary work?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the author's intentions and biographical information.

options.label: B
options.text: To narrow down the concept for analysis and identify patterns.

options.label: C
options.text: To summarize the plot and main characters.

options.label: D
options.text: To evaluate the literary work's historical significance.

multiple-choice.question: What should be avoided when writing an introduction to a literary analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing historical context and background information.

options.label: B
options.text: Using famous quotations, dictionary definitions, or rhetorical questions.

options.label: C
options.text: Including a thesis statement and analysis.

options.label: D
options.text: Using anecdotes and personal experiences.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of a thesis statement in a literary analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: To summarize the plot and main characters.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide historical context and background information.

options.label: C
options.text: To serve as the foundation for the rest of the essay, including the introduction.

options.label: D
options.text: To evaluate the literary work's historical significance.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to take time crafting and revising the thesis and introduction?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure the essay meets the required word count.

options.label: B
options.text: To guarantee a high grade on the assignment.

options.label: C
options.text: To engage the reader and make the essay more interesting.

options.label: D
options.text: To follow the instructor's guidelines and requirements.

title: The art of the metaphor - Jane Hirshfield

multiple-choice.question: What is a metaphor, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A way to talk about one thing by describing something else.

options.label: B
options.text: A way to describe an abstract idea directly.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to compare two things using logic.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to describe a scientific concept.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a metaphor and a simile, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A metaphor is a comparison that admits it's making a comparison, while a simile is not.

options.label: B
options.text: A simile is a comparison that admits it's making a comparison, while a metaphor is not.

options.label: C
options.text: A metaphor is a comparison that uses the word "like," while a simile does not.

options.label: D
options.text: A simile is a comparison that uses the word "as," while a metaphor does not.

options.text: Only in poetry.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Only in scientific writing.

options.text: It leaves you confused.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes you think logically.

options.label: C
options.text: It lets you feel things directly.

options.label: D
options.text: It conveys hidden meanings.

options.label: A
options.text: To convey scientific concepts.

options.label: B
options.text: To describe abstract ideas directly.

options.label: C
options.text: To go beyond their own meaning.

options.label: D
options.text: To describe everyday experiences.

title: Newton’s 3 Laws, with a bicycle - Joshua Manley

multiple-choice.question: What is Newton's First Law, also known as the Law of Inertia?

options.label: A
options.text: Objects in motion tend to slow down and objects at rest tend to speed up.

options.label: B
options.text: Objects in motion tend to stay in motion and objects at rest tend to stay at rest.

options.label: C
options.text: Objects in motion tend to change direction and objects at rest tend to move.

options.label: D
options.text: Objects in motion tend to stop and objects at rest tend to move.

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's Second Law, what is the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration?

options.label: A
options.text: Force is the product of mass divided by acceleration.

options.label: B
options.text: Force is the product of mass times acceleration.

options.label: C
options.text: Force is the product of acceleration divided by mass.

options.label: D
options.text: Force is the product of mass and acceleration squared.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has less inertia.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it requires more force to accelerate.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it requires less force to accelerate.

multiple-choice.question: What is Newton's Third Law?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: For every action, there is a greater reaction.

options.label: C
options.text: For every action, there is a lesser reaction.

options.label: D
options.text: For every action, there is no reaction.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the tires push backward against the ground.

options.label: D

options.text: What goes up, must come down.

options.label: B
options.text: F = G x M1 x M2 / R^2

options.label: C
options.text: The force of attraction between two objects is proportional to their masses.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The rock and the earth move away from each other.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The farther two objects are, the stronger their gravitational attraction.

options.label: C
options.text: The distance between two objects has no effect on their gravitational attraction.

options.label: D
options.text: The closer two objects are, the stronger their gravitational attraction.

options.label: D

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem that the king of Sicily asked Archimedes to solve?

options.text: To investigate if a goldsmith had cheated him by mixing silver into a crown.

options.text: To calculate the volume of a bathtub.

options.text: A measure of an object's shape divided by its volume.

options.label: C

options.label: D
